title.children: Hamas suspends hostage negotiations due to their claims that Israel is targeting hospitals

title.children: Kiribati president reluctant for climate change resettlement deal with Australia

image.altText: Close up of a man with dairy cows in the background

title.children: After battling floods, farmers in NSW now face the next big dry

title.children: Why marijuana users are worried corporations will replace drug dealers

image.altText: picture of a polar bear on ice

items.synopsis: A study of a thousand glaciers in the area shows the rate of melting entering a new phase over the last two decades.

title.children: Melting of all Greenland's glaciers 'in full swing' as speed of ice thaw increases fivefold

image.altText: A composite image of five women, side by side

items.synopsis: Forget rising costs and endless waitlists, these parents can't get any access to child care at all. And it's fuelling calls for government intervention.

title.children: Sacrificing careers, becoming experts on childcare policy: Meet the women finding their way in a market that's failed them

image.altText: O'Neil stands at the despatch box, Anthony Albanese sitting behind her.

items.synopsis: Fearing that telecommunications companies have been left to manage their own cyber affairs with limited oversight, the home affairs minister imposes new reporting obligations in an attempt to prevent another Optus-style hack.

title.children: Optus and other telcos to be forced to report to government on how they manage cyber security

image.altText: The silhouette of several people, some holidng Palestinian flags

items.synopsis: Global Palestinian solidarity demonstrations are getting bigger, but whether taking to the streets will make a difference to government policy is up for debate, writes Riley Stuart.

title.children: When the crowd chants 'ceasefire now', this is why some governments remain 'deaf'

image.altText: Empty classroom with several empty chairs and tables, set against large windows.

items.synopsis: After the disability royal commission called for the phasing out of special schools, it put the spotlight on how mainstream education could support more students with disability.

title.children: Not everyone agrees special schools should be phased out. But there's consensus about one thing

image.altText: Brett and Eddy wearing suits, looking serious, smoke behind them, holding violins.

items.synopsis: Brisbane violinists Brett Yang and Eddy Chen left coveted orchestra jobs to pursue YouTube stardom. This is how the duo built a social media audience of 7.5 million.

title.children: How two Brisbane violinists became global disruptors of classical music

image.altText: The woman's hands lie in her lap, she has pink nail polish and wears a leopard-print skirt.

items.synopsis: The woman who was choked by Tongan man Seti Moala in April last year speaks of the trauma she experienced both during the attack and again as the case went to trial.

title.children: This woman was choked by a man in a Canberra motel room. She says she wasn't given a fair trial

title.children: Do you think fashion is shallow? Celeste Barber is here to challenge that view

title.children: 'Vomit smells everywhere': Cruise ship's COVID, gastro outbreaks declared over as passengers disembark in Adelaide

image.altText: The Australian women's rugby sevens team celebrates with the Oceania Rugby Sevens championship trophy

items.synopsis: Australia wins the women's Oceania Rugby Sevens championship in Brisbane, and the performance of a code-hopping star on a wing raises hopes for a big year ahead.

image.altText: Flames lap outside a window.

items.synopsis: A bushfire destroys at least two homes and forces two dozen people to shelter at a boat ramp overnight at the Tasmanian east coast community of Dolphin Sands.

title.children: Homes destroyed, locals shelter at boat ramp as bushfire hits Tasmanian beachside community

image.altText: ANZ

items.synopsis: Australian shares are down, led by a substantial drop in ANZ's share price as its full-year profit misses market forecasts. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ANZ shares smashed as $7.1b profit disappoints, ASX slips on banks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A mixed report card from two of the big accounting firms for the major banks' profit results. Analysis by EY shows the big four posted a combined statutory profit of $32 billion for the past financial year, up $2.4 billion or 8.2% from the previous year. Net interest margins — the gap between what the banks pay to borrow money and the rates they lend it out at — were up 0.11 of a percentage point to 1.85%. Return on equity, a key measure of profitability, climbed 1.25 percentage points to 12%. But KPMG's analysis highlights the difference between the first and second half of the financial year for the big banks. "The RBA's tightening of monetary policy was the key driver of net interest margins, which increased by an average of 9 basis points on FY22 across the Majors," KPMG's report noted. "The average net interest margin for the Majors was 1.90% in the first half year, which decreased to 1.84% in the second half of FY23. In combination with an increase in interest-earning assets of 7.3 percent compared to FY22, net interest income increased by 13.8 percent to $74.9 billion. " Margins are however under pressure from both intense pricing competition, particularly in the home loan market, as well as the rising cost of deposit and wholesale funding." It's that pressure on profit margins that's seen some of the banks' results, like ANZ's today, poorly received.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Big banks post combined $32 billion in full-year earnings, but trend is weakening

children.content: A mixed report card from two of the big accounting firms for the major banks' profit results.
Analysis by EY
shows the big four posted a
combined statutory profit of $32 billion
for the past financial year, up $2.4 billion or 8.2% from the previous year.
Net interest margins — the gap between what the banks pay to borrow money and the rates they lend it out at — were up 0.11 of a percentage point to 1.85%.
Return on equity, a key measure of profitability, climbed 1.25 percentage points to 12%.
But
KPMG's analysis
highlights the difference between the first and second half of the financial year for the big banks.
"The
RBA's tightening of monetary policy was the key driver of net interest margins
, which increased by an average of 9 basis points on FY22 across the Majors," KPMG's report noted.

"The average net interest margin for the Majors was 1.90% in the first half year, which decreased to 1.84% in the second half of FY23. In combination with an increase in interest-earning assets of 7.3 percent compared to FY22, net interest income increased by 13.8 percent to $74.9 billion.
Margins are however under pressure from both intense pricing competition
, particularly in the home loan market, as well as the rising cost of deposit and wholesale funding."
It's that pressure on profit margins that's seen some of the banks' results, like ANZ's today, poorly received.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More from David Chau down at the UBS conference in Sydney. The chair of the Future Fund (and former Howard-era treasurer) Peter Costello is also speaking at the UBS Australasia Conference. Mr Costello says Australia's current levels of immigration (at around 500,000 to 600,000 migrants annually) are "extremely high". "It was about 120,000 [people] back in my day," he said. "This is an enormous adjustment for our economy, and it's no wonder we're seeing rental shortages." He also noted that the RBA has identified rent as a significant driver of inflation in the near term. While Mr Costello stressed he was "pro-immigration", he said it's important that it needs to be handled in a "gradualised" way. Mr Costello was also critical of the Reserve Bank's decision to cut interest rates to near-zero at the height of the pandemic (along with similar decisions by many other central banks worldwide). He said a 0% interest rate is "corrosive to society", "fuels asset booms", and is a problem for people with "no assets". He noted, in the US, it was "better for Wall Street than main street" (ie low rates disproportionately favoured the wealthy over the poor and middle class). Mr Costello said the current problem of "entrenched inflation" is because central banks did not lift rates again quickly enough — and that monetary policy has "run its course" (ie that it is up to governments to take a more active part in managing supply/demand and inflation dynamics).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Costello: Low interest rates 'corrosive to society', 'gradualised' migration necessary

children.content: More from
David Chau
down at the UBS conference in Sydney.
The
chair of the Future Fund (and former Howard-era treasurer) Peter Costello
is also speaking at the UBS Australasia Conference.
Mr Costello says Australia's current levels of immigration (at around 500,000 to 600,000 migrants annually) are "extremely high".
"It was about 120,000 [people] back in my day," he said.
"This is an enormous adjustment for our economy, and it's no wonder we're seeing rental shortages."
He also noted that the RBA has identified rent as a significant driver of inflation in the near term.
While Mr Costello stressed he was "pro-immigration", he said it's important that it needs to be handled in a "gradualised" way.
Mr Costello was also critical of the Reserve Bank's decision to cut interest rates to near-zero at the height of the pandemic (along with similar decisions by many other central banks worldwide).
He said a 0% interest rate is "corrosive to society", "fuels asset booms", and is a problem for people with "no assets".
He noted, in the US, it was "better for Wall Street than main street" (ie low rates disproportionately favoured the wealthy over the poor and middle class).

Mr Costello said the current problem of "entrenched inflation" is because central banks did not lift rates again quickly enough — and that monetary policy has "run its course" (ie that it is up to governments to take a more active part in managing supply/demand and inflation dynamics).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX futures turned negative late on before the actual market open, and that's carried over into early trading. In terms of index points, ANZ is the big drag, with the banking giant slumping 3.4% to $24.60 after a $7.1 billion profit result that clearly disappointed investors. ANZ's fall was leading to a 0.7% decline across the financial sector. The other biggest loser on the ASX 200 is TPG Telecom, off 8.4% to $4.99 after the company pulled the plug on discussions with Vocus, which was looking to buy some of its enterprise, government and wholesale assets, including Vision Network. Unlike in the US, Australia's tech sector index was down 0.3%. Utilities, mining and energy were all in the black in early trade. Biggest gains: Elders +10% to $6.80 Boral +6.8% to $5.01 NIB Holdings +4.1% to $7.59 Light and Wonder +2.3% to $134.61 Incitec Pivot +2.2% to $2.965 Biggest losses: TPG Telecom -8.3% to $5 ANZ -3.3% to $24.635 Chalice Mining -2.8% to $1.59 Perseus Mining -2.6% to $1.695 Macquarie Group -2.5% to $158.62
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as ANZ, TPG shares smashed

image.altText: Two men in suits shaking hands, Parliament House and $100 notes in the background.

items.synopsis: Identified in Parliament House by their orange access passes, lobbyists are free to wander the halls, governed not by laws but by a code of conduct. But the standard of regulation in the industry has been deplored by both integrity experts and independent politicians.

title.children: In Canberra, the lobbyists outnumber the politicians. One MP is now proposing an overhaul to curb their influence

image.altText: Saturn and its rings on a pitch black background.

items.synopsis: In the past few days, a slew of articles have run like wildfire through social media. Saturn's rings, those articles claim, are rapidly disappearing — and will be gone by 2025! So what's the story?

title.children: Could the next couple of months be our last chance to see Saturn's mighty rings?
